DOC.HEAD: Breeden Wants To Cut Out Squabbles Over New Products
DOC.TEXT: Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden says he'd like to see federal futures law ``repealed or modified'' to prevent interagency squabbles over new financial products. Breeden used a news conference Monday on cooperation agreements with French and Dutch securities regulators to repeat his complaint about jurisdictional disputes with the rival Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Such disputes were keeping new ``hybrid'' financial products ``in the courthouse instead of in the marketplace'' while foreign exchanges were trading in similar products, said Breeden. He suggested repealing or amending the Commodity Exchange Act, which governs the futures industry, ``to let the markets decide where the products will be most actively traded.'' Breeden also announced he is creating an Office of International Affairs to coordinate enforcement cooperation with foreign stock regulators. The new international affairs office will be headed by Michael D. Mann, now an associate director for international affairs in the SEC's Enforcement Division. Breeden said the new office, which will be responsible for negotiating formal cooperation agreements, known as memoranda of understanding, ``underlines the very high priority the commission places on international cooperation.'' While the SEC is ``concerned a great deal about maintaining regulatory cooperation,'' said Breeden, ``we at the commission are also very concerned about competitive issues.'' Hybrid products are securities with elements of commodity futures, or futures with elements of a security. Earlier this year, a federal appeals court in Chicago ruled the SEC overstepped its authority when it approved trading in a type of hybrid instrument known as an index participation, or IP. IPs, which have been likened to baskets of stocks, may not be traded in U.S. markets until the dispute, which is still in the courts, is resolved. Breeden first spoke out against the jurisdictional disputes to securities lawyers last month in Washington. Such litigation delays are ``a direct threat to American competitiveness'' in the financial trading markets, Breeden said Monday. ``Our foreign competitors have not imposed this type of restriction on themselves.'' He cited a recent story in the Financial Times of London that a consortium of European business people planned to offer a stock basket product, similar to the one blocked in the United States. Breeden said that ``early next year we hope to work together with the CFTC and discuss with Congress ways of moving this unneccessary barrier to our competitiveness.'' David Gary, a CFTC spokesman, said Monday: ``We will be meeting and have been meeting with fellow regulators, particularly the SEC. We feel there are a number of questions that relate to the financial services industry. We are more than willing to sit down and discuss them, but we want to see them answered with the big picture in mind. Futures are not isolated by themselves.'' Last week, Breeden signed cooperation agreements with Dutch and French securities regulators that will allow the exchange of information to help stamp out insider trading and other market abuses. Breeden said Monday he would travel to Japan in mid-January as part of an ongoing series of visits both countries have exchanged since signing a limited cooperation agreement in 1986. Breeden, who was sworn into office in October, said he expected the talks would cover enforcement topics as well as capital rules, disclosure and other matters. On another matter, Breeden declined to discuss when he would name a director to head the SEC's Enforcement Division.
